paragraphs.text:
%spark println(s"""%html

The U.S. Department of Transportation's (DOT) Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) tracks the on-time performance of domestic flights operated by large air carriers.
Summary information on the number of on-time, delayed, canceled and diverted flights is available for the last 20 years.
In this example we used the 2009-2015 data set (40 million records) and show simple analytic queries on "exact" as well as "sampled" data.You will be able to compare the response times and be able to inspect the accuracy differences.

The data set used here is relatively small (few GB of Parquet formatted data). The interesting thing about using stratified sampling is that the error rate drops exponentially with the size of the sample. The exponential error drop off implies with larger data sets, the sampling fraction can also keep getting smaller. e.g. you may need a 2 million sample for a data set with 200 million records, but, may only need a 3 million sample for a data set with a billion records to achieve the same level of accuracy.

You can always share your thoughts/questions or just encourage us at http://www.snappydata.io/community

(You can use slack,Gitter,stackoverflow , or google groups)
Or, just send an email to chomp@snappydata.io""")

msg.data:
The U.S. Department of Transportation's (DOT) Bureau of Transportation Statistics (BTS) tracks the on-time performance of domestic flights operated by large air carriers.
Summary information on the number of on-time, delayed, canceled and diverted flights is available for the last 20 years.
In this example we used the 2009-2015 data set (40 million records) and show simple analytic queries on "exact" as well as "sampled" data.You will be able to compare the response times and be able to inspect the accuracy differences.

The data set used here is relatively small (few GB of Parquet formatted data). The interesting thing about using stratified sampling is that the error rate drops exponentially with the size of the sample. The exponential error drop off implies with larger data sets, the sampling fraction can also keep getting smaller. e.g. you may need a 2 million sample for a data set with 200 million records, but, may only need a 3 million sample for a data set with a billion records to achieve the same level of accuracy.

You can always share your thoughts/questions or just encourage us at http://www.snappydata.io/community

(You can use slack,Gitter,stackoverflow , or google groups)
Or, just send an email to chomp@snappydata.io

paragraphs.title: Monitor the cluster, check memory consumption
paragraphs.text:
%spark println(s"""%html
SnappyData Pulse UI
The Dashboard tab in the SnappyData Pulse UI can be used to monitor the cluster and check the memory consumed by the samples.
""")

msg.data:
SnappyData Pulse UI
The Dashboard tab in the SnappyData Pulse UI can be used to monitor the cluster and check the memory consumed by the samples.

paragraphs.title: Load data from Parquet files into Exact and Sample Table
Alternatively, load program using SQL (Run the above para or this one, NOT BOTH )
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

CREATE SAMPLE TABLE AIRLINE_SAMPLE ON AIRLINE_large OPTIONS(
    buckets '33', qcs 'UniqueCarrier, Year, Month',
    fraction '0.001', 
    strataReservoirSize '50', persistent 'sync') 
  AS (SELECT * FROM AIRLINE_large);

%spark println(s"""%html

Now, lets do some analytics - queries on the left paragraphs go against the full("exact") data. The right side paras run against the stratified sample created above. While the difference in performance is 5-10X (left vs right paragraphs) larger volume or concurrency makes the difference more stark. For example, you can RUN several of the left paragraphs concurrently and try the same on the right paragraphs to see the effect of concurrency on response time.

""")

msg.data: Now, lets do some analytics - queries on the left paragraphs go against the full("exact") data. The right side paras run against the stratified sample created above. While the difference in performance is 5-10X (left vs right paragraphs) larger volume or concurrency makes the difference more stark. For example, you can RUN several of the left paragraphs concurrently and try the same on the right paragraphs to see the effect of concurrency on response time.

paragraphs.title: TIBCO COMPUTEDB PERFORMANCE
TIBCO COMPUTEDB AQP PERFORMANCE
How many records do we have?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select count(*) from AIRLINE_large

msg.data:
count(1) 1003279752
Time required to execute query : 194 millis.

paragraphs.title: How many records in the synopsis table?

msg.data:
ROWCOUNT SAMPLE_COUNT 1003279752 1047059
Time required to execute query : 251 millis.

paragraphs.title: what is the best day of the week to travel?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select dayofweek, AVG(ArrDelay) avgDelay from airline_large
group by dayofweek
order by dayofweek

paragraphs.title: what is the best day of the week to travel?   (Use Synopsis)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select dayofweek, AVG(ArrDelay) avgDelay from airline_large
group by dayofweek
order by dayofweek with error
%md

paragraphs.title: Busiest airports over 20 years (Full data)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
select count(*) cnt, destAirportName destination from airline_large t1, airline_dest t2 where t1.dest = t2.destIATA group by destination order by count(*) desc limit 8;

msg.data:
CNT DESTINATION 53264599 Chicago O'Hare International Airport 52263306 Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta International Airport 46919296 Dallas Fort Worth International Airport 33087048 Los Angeles International Airport 28119039 Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport 26798517 Denver International Airport 24050589 Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport 23200160 George Bush Intercontinental Houston Airport
Time required to execute query : 2873 millis.

paragraphs.title: Busiest airports over 20 years (Synopses)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql
select count(*) cnt, destAirportName destination from airline_large t1, airline_dest t2 where t1.dest = t2.destIATA group by destination order by count(*) desc limit 8 with error ;

msg.data:
CNT DESTINATION 52914880 Chicago O'Hare International Airport 51883980 Hartsfield Jackson Atlanta International Airport 46430887 Dallas Fort Worth International Airport 33620308 Los Angeles International Airport 28187410 Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport 27282487 Denver International Airport 24218730 Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport 22976395 George Bush Intercontinental Houston Airport
Time required to execute query : 375 millis.

paragraphs.text: %snappydata.sql

paragraphs.title: Which airline has the most flights?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select  count(*)  cnt, description airlineName from AIRLINE_ext, AIRLINEREF
where airline_ext.UniqueCarrier = airlineref.Code 
group by description  order by cnt desc limit 8

msg.data:
CNT	AIRLINENAME
188383860	Southwest Airlines Co.
104979840	Delta Air Lines Inc.
96977060	SkyWest Airlines Inc.
92002980	American Airlines Inc.
75684200	ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
74317920	Envoy Air
71521200	United Air Lines Inc.
69278380	US Airways Inc.

paragraphs.title: Which airline has the most flights?   (Use Synopsis)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select  count(*)  cnt, description airlineName from AIRLINE_mem, AIRLINEREF_CACHE
where airline_mem.UniqueCarrier = airlineref_cache.Code 
group by description  order by cnt desc limit 8 with error 0.2

msg.data:
CNT	AIRLINENAME
188383860	Southwest Airlines Co.
104979840	Delta Air Lines Inc.
96977060	SkyWest Airlines Inc.
92002980	American Airlines Inc.
75684200	ExpressJet Airlines Inc.
74317920	Envoy Air
71521200	United Air Lines Inc.
69278380	US Airways Inc.

paragraphs.text: %md

paragraphs.title: Which airlines arrive on schedule?
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select AVG(ArrDelay) arrivalDelay, UniqueCarrier carrier from airline_large group by UniqueCarrier
order by UniqueCarrier

paragraphs.title: Which airlines arrive on schedule?   (Use Synopsis)
paragraphs.text:
%snappydata.sql

select AVG(ArrDelay) arrivalDelay, UniqueCarrier carrier from airline_large group by UniqueCarrier
order by UniqueCarrier with error 0.1 confidence 0.8 behavior 'do_nothing'

paragraphs.title: How is arrival delay trending over the years?
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc

SELECT AVG(ArrDelay) ArrivalDelay, UniqueCarrier, Year_
	   FROM airline_ext GROUP BY UniqueCarrier, Year_ ORDER BY
	        Year_,UniqueCarrier desc limit 100

paragraphs.title: How is arrival delay trending over the years?   (Use Synopsis)
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc 

SELECT AVG(ArrDelay) ArrivalDelay, UniqueCarrier, Year_
	   FROM airline_sample GROUP BY UniqueCarrier, Year_ ORDER BY
	         Year_,UniqueCarrier desc limit 100

paragraphs.title: Which are the worst airports?
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc

select avg(DepDelay) delay, Origin, count(*) AS cnt 
from airline_ext group by Origin having cnt > 500000 order by delay desc limit 10

paragraphs.title: Which are the worst airports? (Query Synopsis table directly )
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc 

select avg(DepDelay) delay, Origin, count(*) as cnt, count(*) as sample_count, absolute_error(delay)
from airline_sample group by Origin having cnt > 500000 order by delay desc limit 10

paragraphs.title: what is the best day of the week to travel?
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc
select  DayOfWeek, AVG(ArrDelay) avgDelay from airline_ext
group by DayOfWeek
order by  avgDelay desc

paragraphs.title: what is the best day of the week to travel?   (Use Synopsis)
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc

select  DayOfWeek, AVG(ArrDelay) avgDelay from airline_sample
group by DayOfWeek
order by  avgDelay desc
